title: Why cleaning matters
body: Cleaning removes visible dirt, grease and food residues. Disinfection kills bacteria and viruses that survive cleaning. Skipping either step lets harmful microorganisms spread to food, equipment or hands.

title: The cleaning cycle
body: A correct clean follows four steps: Clean, Rinse, Disinfect, Air Dry. Never skip rinsing — disinfectant won’t work on dirty surfaces, and wiping dry can re-contaminate them.

title: Contact times
body: Every disinfectant has a required contact time — often 30 seconds. Spraying and wiping straight away means bacteria survive. Read the product label and let it sit for the full contact time.

title: Cross-contamination in action
caption: Particles moving from raw to ready foods. Always separate tools, boards and storage areas.

prompt: Click the areas where bacteria might hide.

title: Shortcut cleaning
stem: After a busy lunch service you see a colleague spray and immediately wipe a food counter. What should you do?

options.label: Say nothing — it looks clean.
options.result: Wrong. Bacteria remain because the disinfectant had no time to work.

options.label: Remind them to wait the full contact time.
options.result: Correct. You’ve prevented a cross-contamination risk.

bullets: Follow contact times on cleaning products.
Use colour-coded tools to separate raw and ready areas.
Let surfaces dry completely before food prep.
